Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Hive \Hive\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Hived}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Hiving}.] 1. To collect into a hive; to place in, or cause to enter, a hive; as, to hive a swarm of bees. [1913 Webster]
2. To store up in a hive, as honey; hence, to gather and accumulate for future need; to lay up in store. [1913 Webster]
Hiving wisdom with each studious year. --Byron. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Hive \Hive\, n. [OE. hive, huve, AS. h?fe.] 1. A box, basket, or other structure, for the reception and habitation of a swarm of honeybees. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]
2. The bees of one hive; a swarm of bees. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
3. A place swarming with busy occupants; a crowd. [1913 Webster]
The hive of Roman liars. --Tennyson. [1913 Webster]
{Hive bee} (Zo["o]l.), the honeybee. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Hive \Hive\, v. i. To take shelter or lodgings together; to reside in a collective body. --Pope. [1913 Webster]

hive n 1: a teeming multitude 2: a man-made receptacle that houses a swarm of bees [syn: {beehive}] 3: a structure that provides a natural habitation for bees; as in a hollow tree [syn: {beehive}] v 1: store, like bees; "bees hive honey and pollen"; "He hived lots of information" 2: move together in a hive or as if in a hive; "The bee swarms are hiving" 3: gather into a hive; "The beekeeper hived the swarm"
